sp.p: Why, this is excellent, I will go fetch the cream.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: And I the cake.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And I the spoon.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: See where he comes as like the lord Dowsecer as may be, now you shall hear him begin with some Latin sentence that he hath remembered ever since he read his Accidence.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Felix que faciunt aliena pericula cautum. O silly state of things, for things they be that cause this silly state: and what is a thing, a bauble, a toy, that stands men in small stead:
but what have we here? what vanities have we here?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: He is strongly tempted, the lord strengthen him, see what a vain he hath.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: O cruel fortune, and dost thou spit thy spite at my poor life: but O sour cream what thinkest thou that I love thee still? no, no, fair and sweet is my mistress, if thou hadst strawberries and sugar in thee: but it may be thou art set with stale cake to choke me: well taste it, and try it, spoonful by spoonful: bitterer and bitterer still, but O sour cream, wert thou an Onion, since Fortune set thee for me, I will eat thee, and I will devour thee in spite of Fortunes spite, choke I, or burst I, mistress for thy sake, to end my life eat I this cream and cake.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: So he hath done, his Melancholy is well eased I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Gods my life Gentlemen, who hath been at this cream?

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Cream, had you cream? where is your cream? I will spend my penny at your cream.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Why, did not you eat this cream?

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Talk not to me of cream, for such vain meat I do despise as food, my stomach dies drowned in the cream bowls of my mistress eyes.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Nay stay Labesha.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: No not I, not I.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: O he is ashamed i'faith: but I will tell thee how thou shalt make him mad indeed, say his mistress for love of him hath drowned herself.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: 'Sblood, that will make him hang himself.

body.stage: Enter the Queene, Lemot, and all the rest of the lordes, and the Countesse: Lemots arme in a scarffe.

sp.speaker: Lemot.
sp.p: have at them i'faith with a lame counterfeit humour: ache on rude arm, I care not for thy pain, I got it nobly in the kings defence, and in the guardiance of my fair Queens right.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: O tell me sweet Lemot how fares the king? or what his right was that thou didst defend?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: That you shall know when other things are told.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Keep not the Queen too long without her longing.

sp.speaker: Foyes.
sp.p: No, for I tell you it is a dangerous thing.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: Little care cruel men how women long.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: What would you have me then put poison in my breath, and burn the ears of my attentive Queen.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Tell me what ere it be, I will bear it all.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: bear with my rudeness then in telling it, for alas you see I can but act it with the left hand, this is my gesture now.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: It is well enough.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Yea well enough you say, this recompense have I for all my wounds: then thus the King enamoured of an other lady compares your face to hers, and says that yours is fat and flat, and that your nether lip was passing big.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: O wicked man, doth he so suddenly condemn my beauty, that when he married me he thought divine: forever blasted be that strumpets face, as all my hopes are blasted, that did change them.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Nay Madam, though he said your face was fat, and flat, and so forth, yet he liked it best, and said, a perfect beauty should be so.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O did he so! why that was right even as it should be.

sp.speaker: Foy.
sp.p: You see now Madam, how much too hasty you were in your griefs.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.p: If he did so esteem of me indeed, happy am I.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: So may your highness be that hath so good a husband, but hell hath no plague to such an one as I.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Indeed Madam, you have a bad husband: truly then did the king grow mightily in love with the other lady, and swore, no king could more enriched be, than to enjoy so fair a dame as she.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: O monstrous man, and accursed most miserable dame!

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: But says the king I do enjoy as fair, and; though I love in all honoured sort, yet I will not wrong my wife for all the world

sp.speaker: Foy.
sp.p: This proves his constancy as firm as brass.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.p: It doth, it doth: O pardon me my lord, that I mistake thy royal meaning so.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: In heaven your highness lives, but I in hell.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: But when he viewed her radiant eyes again, blind was he strucken with her fervent beams: and now good King he gropes about in corners void of the cheerful light should guide us all.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.p: O dismal news, what is my sovereign blind?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Blind as a Beetle madam, that a while hovering aloft, at last in cow-sheds fall.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Could her eyes blind him?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Eyes or what it was I know not, but blind I am sure he is as any stone.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Come bring me to my Prince my lord that I may lead him, none alive but I may have the honour to direct his feet.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: How lead him madam? why he can go as right as you, or any here, and is not blind of eyesight.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Of what then?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Of reason.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Why thou saidest he wanted his cheerful light.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Of reason still I meant, whose light you know should cheerfully guide a worthy King, for he doth love her, and hath forced her into a private room where now they are.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What mocking changes is there in thy words fond man, thou murtherest me with these exclaims.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: Why madam it is your fault, you cut me off before my words be half done.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Forth and unlade the poison of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Another lord did love this curious lady, who hearing that the King had forced her, as she was walking with another Earl, ran straightaways mad for her, and with a friend of his, and two or three black ruffians more, brake desperately upon the person of the King, swearing to take from him, in traitorous fashion, the instrument of procreation: with them I fought a while, and got this wound, but being unable to resist so many, came straight to you to fetch you to his aid.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Why raised you not the streets?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: That I forbore, because I would not have the world, to see what a disgrace my liege was subject to, being with a woman in so mean a house.

sp.speaker: Foy.
sp.p: Whose daughter was it that he forced I pray?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Your daughter sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Whose son was that ran so mad for her?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Your son my Lord.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O Gods, and fiends forbid.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: I pray sir, from whom did he take the Lady?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: From your good Lord.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: O Lord I beseech thee no.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: It is all too true, come follow the Queen and I, where I shall lead you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O wretched Queen, what would they take from him?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: The instrument of procreation.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Now was there ever man so much accursed, that when his mind misgave him, such a man was hapless, to keep him company? yet who would keep him company but I, O vild Lemot, my wife and I are bound to curse thee while we live, but chiefly I, well: seek her, or seek her not; find her, or find her not, I were as good see how hell opens, as look upon her.

body.stage: Enter Catalian, and Berger behind him.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: We have i'faith, stop thou him there, and I will meet him here.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Well, I will venture once to seek her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Gods Lord, my Lord, come you this way, why your wife runs ranging like as if she were mad, swearing to slit your nose if she can catch you.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: What shall I do at the sight of her and hern.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Gods precious my Lord, come you this way, your wife comes ranging with a troop of dames, like Bacchus drunken foes, just as you go, shift for yourself my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Stay good Catalian.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: No not I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: How now Iaques, what is the news?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: None but good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Why hast not seen my wife run round about the streets.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Not I my Lord, I come to you from my master, who would pray you to speak to Lemot, that Lemot might speak to the King, that my masters lottery for his jewels may go forward, he hath made the rarest device that ever you heard, we have fortune in it, and she our maid plays, and I, and my fellow carry two torches, and our boy goes before and speaks a speech, it is very fine i'faith sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Sirrah in this thou mayst highly pleasure me, let me have thy place to bear a torch, that I may look on my wife, and she not see me, for if I come into her sight abruptly, I were better be hanged.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: O sir you shall, or anything that I can do, I will send for your wife too .

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I prithee do.

body.stage: Enter the Queene, and all that were in before.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: This is the house where the mad Lord did vow to do the deed, draw all your swords courageous gentlemen, I will bring you there where you shall honour win, but I can tell you, you must break your shin.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Who will not break his neck to save his King: set forward Lemot.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Yea, much good can I do with a wounded arm, I will go and call more help.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Others shall go, nay we will raise the streets, better dishonour, than destroy the King.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: 'Sblood I know not how to excuse my villainy, I would fain be gone.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: I will geld the adulterous goat, and take from him the instrument, that plays him such sweet music.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O rare, this makes my fiction true: now I will stay.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Arrest these faithless traitorous gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: What is the reason that you call us traitors?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, why do you attempt such violence against the person of the King?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Against the King, why this is strange to me.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: How now my masters, what? weapons drawn, come you to murder me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: How fares my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Lemot How fare I? well, but you i'faith shall get me speak for you another time; he got me here to woo a curious Lady, and she tempts him, say what I can, over what state I will in your behalf Lemot, she will not yield.

sp.speaker: Le,
sp.p: i'faith my liege, what a hard heart hath she, well hark you, I am content your wit shall save your honesty for this once.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Peace, a plague on you, peace; but wherefore asked you how I did?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: Because I feared that you were hurt my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Hurt, how I pray?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Why, hurt Madam, I am well again.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Do you ask? why he told me Dowsecer and this his friend, threatened to take away.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: To take away, what should they take away.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Name it Madam.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Nay, I pray name it you.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Why then, thus it was my liege, I told her and this his friend threatened to take away, and if they could the instrument of procreation, and what was that now, but Martia being a fair woman, is not she the instrument of procreation, as all women are.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: O wicked man.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Go to, go to, you are one of those fiddles too i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Well pardon my minion, that hath frayed, you thus, it was but to make you merry in the end.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: I joy it ends so well, my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.p: But say my gracious Lord, is no harm done, between my loving daughter, and your grace?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: No, of my honour and my soul Foyes.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: The fire of love which she hath kindled in me being greater than my heat of vanity, hath quite expelled.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Come Dowsecer receive with your lost wits your love, though lost; I know you will yield, my lord and you her father.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: Most joyfully my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: And for her part I know her disposition well enough.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: What, will you have her?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Yea marry will I.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: I will go and tell Labesha presently.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Monsieur Lemot I pray let me speak with you, I come to you from the Lord Moren, who would desire you to speak to the King for my masters lottery, and he hath my place to bear a torch, for bare faced he dares not look upon his wife, for his life.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: O excellent, I will further thy masters lottery and it be but for this jest only, hark you my liege, here is the poor man hath been at great charges for the preparation of a lottery, and he hath made the rarest device, that I know you will take great pleasure in it, I pray let him present it before you at Valeres house.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: With all my heart, can you be ready so soon?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Presently and if it like your grace.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: But hark you Lemot, how shall we do for every man's posy.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Will you all trust me with the making of them?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Why then I will go to make the poses and bring Labesha to the lottery presently.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Surely the world is full of vanity, a woman must take heed she do not hear a lewd man speak, for every woman cannot when she is tempted, when the wicked fiend gets her into his snares escape like me, for graces measure is not so filled up, nor so pressed down in everyone as me, but yet I promise you a little more: well, I will go seek my head, who shall take me in the gates of his kind arms untouched of any.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What Madam are you so pure now?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yea, would not you be pure?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No puritan.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You must be then a devil. I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: O wife where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: where did I tell you I would be I pray.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: In thy close walk thou saidst.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And was I not?

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Truly I know not, I neither looked nor knocked, for Labesha told me that you, and fair Martia were at Verones ordinary.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Labesha? my lord you are a wise man to believe a fool.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well my good head, for my part I forgive you: but surely you do much offend to be suspicious: where there is no trust, there is no love, and where there is no love twixt man and wife, there is no good dealing surely: for as men should ever love their wives, so should they ever trust them, for what love is there where there is no trust?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: She tells you true, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: She doth my liege; and dear wife pardon this and will I never be suspicious more.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Why say, I do.

body.stage: Enter Lemot, leading Labesha in a halter.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Look you my liege, I have done simple service amongst you, here is one had hanged himself for love, thinking his Mistress had done so for him: well, see your Mistress lives.

sp.speaker: Labesh.
sp.p: And doth my Mistress live?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: She doth, O noble knight, but not your Mistress now.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: 'Sblood, but she shall for me, or for nobody else.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: How now, what a traitor, draw upon the King.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Yea, or upon any woman here in a good cause.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well sweet Besha let her marry Dowsecer I will get thee a wife worth fifteen of her, wilt thou have one that cares not for thee?

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Not I by the Lord, I scorn her, I will have her better if I can get her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why that is well said.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: What Madam, are you turned puritan again?

sp.speaker: Elo.
sp.p: When was I other, pray?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Marry I will tell you when, when you went to the Ordinary, and when you made false signs to your husband, which I could tell him all.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Cursed be he that maketh debate twixt man and; wife.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: O rare scripturian! you have sealed up my lips, a hall, a hall, the pageant of the Buttery.

body.stage: Enter two with torches, the one of them Moren, then my host and his son, then his maid drest like Queene Fortune with two pots in her hands.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: This is Verones son, my liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What shall he do?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Speak some speech that his father hath made for him

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Why is he good at speeches?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: O he is rare at speeches.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fair ladies most tender, and nobles most slender, and gentles whose wits be scarce.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: My host, why do you call us nobles most slender?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: If it shall please your Grace, to be slender is to be proper, and therefore where my boy says nobles most slender, it is as much to say, fine and proper nobles.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Yea, but why do you call us gentles whose wits are scarce.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: To be scarce, is to be rare: and therefore where as he says Gentles whose wits be scarce, is as much as to say, Gentles whose wits be rare.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: Well, forwards trunchman.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fair ladies most tender, and nobles most slender, and gentles whose wits be scarce, Queen Fortune doth come with her trump, and her drum, as it may appear by my voice.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Come hither, are you a schoolmaster, where was Fortune Queen, of what country or kingdom?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why sir, Fortune was Queen over all the world.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: That is a lie, there is none that ever conquered all the world, but master Alisander, I am sure of that.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: O rare Monsieur Labesha, who would have thought he could have found so rare a fault in the speech.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I will alter it if it please your grace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No, it is very well.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Father I must begin again they interrupt me so.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I beseech your grace give the boy leave to begin again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: With all my heart, it is so good we cannot hear it too oft.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fair ladies most tender, and nobles most slender, and gentles whose wits are scarce, Queen Fortune doth come with her Fife, and her Drum, as it doth appear by my voice, here is Fortune good, but ill by the rood, and this naught but good shall do you, dealing the lots out of our pots, and so good Fortune to you sir.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Look you my liege, how he that caries the torch trembles extremely.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: I warrant it is with care to carry his torch well.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Nay there is something else in the wind: why my host, what means thy man Iaques to tremble so?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Hold still thou knave, what art thou afraid to look upon the goodly presence of a king: hold up for shame.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Alas poor man, he thinks it is Iaques his man: poor lord, how much is he bound to suffer for his wife?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Hark you mine host, what goodly person is that? is it Fortune herself?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I will tell your Majesty in secrete who it is, it is my maid Iaquena.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I promise you she becomes her state rarely.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Well my liege, you were all content that I should make your poses: well here they be every one: give Master Verone his five crowns.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There is mine and the Queens.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: And there is mine and Martias.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Come Labesha thy money.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: You must lend me some, for my boy is run away with my purse.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Thy boy? I never knew any that thou hadst.

sp.speaker: Lab.
sp.p: Had not I a boy three or four years ago, and he ran away.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: And never since he went thou hadst not a penny, but stand by, I will excuse you. But sirrah Catalian, thou shalt stand on one side and read the prises, and I will stand on the other and read the Poses.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: Content Lemot.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Come on Queen Fortune, tell every man his posy, this is orderly, the King and Queen are first.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Come let us see what goodly poses you have given us.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: This is your Majesties, At the fairest, so it be not Martia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: A plague upon you, you are still playing the villains with me.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: This is the Queens, Obey the Queen: and she speaks it to her husband, or to Fortune, which she will.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.p: A prise: your Majesties is the sum of four shillings in gold

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why how can that be there is no such coin.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Here is the worth of it, if it please your grace.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: Well, what is for me?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: A heart of gold.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p: A goodly jewel.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Count Laberuel and Florila.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What is my posy sir I pray?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Marry this my Lord,
Of all fortunes friends, that hath joy in this life,
He is most happy that puts a sure trust in his wife.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A very good one sir, I thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What is mine I pray?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Marry this Madam,
Good fortune be thou my good fortune bringer,
And make me amends for my poor bitten finger.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Who bit your finger wife?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nobody ; it is vain posy.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Blank for my lord Laberuele for his wife a posy, a pair of holy beads with a crucifix.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O bomination Idol, I will none of them.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Keep them thyself Veron, she will not have them.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Dowsecer and Martia I have fitted your lordship for a posy.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Why what is it?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And what is mine sir?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: A serious one I warrant you change: for the better.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: That is not amiss.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: A price: Dowsecer hath a cats eyes or Mercuries rod of gold, set with Jacinths and Emeralds.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: What is for Martia?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Martia hath the two serpents heads set with Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: What my host Uerone?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: What? is he in for his own jewels.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: O what else my liege, it is our bounty, and his posy is
sp.l: To tell you the truth in words plain and mild,
Verone loves his maid, and she is great with child.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: What Queen fortune with child, shall we have young fortunes my host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I am abused, and if it please your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I will play no more.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.l: No faith you need not now, you have played your belly full already

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Stand still good Iaquena they do but jest.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yea, but I like no such jesting.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Come great Queen Fortune, let see your posies, what madam, alas, your ladyship is one of the last.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: What is my posy sir I pray?

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Marry Madam your posy is made in manner and form of an Echo, as if you were seeking your husband, and fortune should be the Echo, and this you say: where is my husband hid so long unmasked, masked? says the Echo, but in what place sweet Fortune? let me hear: hear says the Echo.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There you lie Echo, for if he were here we must needs see him.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: Indeed sweet King, there methinks the Echo must needs lie, if he were here we must needs see him, it is one of them that caries the torches: no that cannot be neither, and yet by the Mass here is why my host, did not you tell me that Iaques should be a torch-bearer: who is this? Gods my life, my lord.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If you be Gentlemen let me go.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: Nay come your way, you may be well enough ashamed to show your face that is a perjured wretch, did not you swear, if there were any wenches at the ordinary, you would straight come home.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why, who told you Madam, there were any there?

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: He that will stand to it Lemot my liege.

sp.speaker: Lem.
sp.p: who I stand to it, alas, I told you in kindness, and good will, because I would not have you company long from your husband.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why lo you bird, how much you are deceived.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Why wherefore were you afraid to be seen?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Who I afraid? alas I bore a torch to grace this honourable presence, for nothing else sweet bird.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Dowsecer Thanks good Moren, see lady with what wrong you have pursued your most enamoured lord: but come now all are friends, now is this day spent with an hurtful motives of delight, and over joys more my senses at the night: and now for Dowsecer, if all will follow my devise, his beauteous love and he shall married be, and here I solemnly invite you all home to my court, where with feasts we will crown this mirthful day, and vow it to renown.
